channel.title: ACTA - worse than PIPA & SOPA
channel.description:
So, the lobbyists are trying to tear down our beloved internet again. [url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Counterfeiting_Trade_Agreement']https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Counterfeiting_Trade_Agreement[/url] [url]https://www.laquadrature.net/acta[/url] [url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=citzRjwk-sQ[/url]
New Blackout, anyone? Or what can we do? Discuss

item.title: ACTA - worse than PIPA & SOPA
item.dc:creator: Medevilae
item.description:
Nerdguy:

Imagine the europeans never discovered america

ACTA tis European

(rot)(fodder:

Maybe all this PIPA/SOPA/ACTA is the U.S’s last ditch effort at dropping their debts and just generally trying not to become China’s bitch.

China’s debt-to-GDP ratio is worse than the US’s- and that’s going on what China says it is, it could be a lot worse.

Read full topic

item.title: ACTA - worse than PIPA & SOPA
item.dc:creator: bur
item.description:
Bolteh:

Get this!

Spotify is free to use, right? You probably also know that Spotify also finds any other media on your computer that which isn’t part of your Spotify library, right? Did you also know that the user agreement of Spotify mentions that they hold the right (and duty) to pass your information to the right instances when they suspect any user from owning pirated music?

If you have Spotify installed and have a lot of pirated songs on your HD, and all of these Big brother bills are passed, you’ll probably go to jail or pay millions and millions of dollars.

The trick is to uninstall Spotify before the end of the 6th month after installing Spotify (that’s when the truly free service ends and Spotify limits you to 10 hours playtime a month and a maximum of 5 listens to a specific song per month). If you have used Spotify for more than 6 months, you’re screwed and have to hope all of these bills never make it through.

Also, share this on Twitter and Facebook, if you get enough likes or retweets, you won’t go to jail or pay a fine.

One problem though: there is no way anyone can tell the difference between legal and illegal music. The only way to tell is by actually checking if the user has an actual physical copy, or if he’s bought it from something like iTunes.

In other words, they’ll just be gathering information about you that they really have no business gathering, and they’ll just be making wild guesses.

Read full topic
